conclusion: To determine if objects A and B have the same acceleration at time \( t_1 \), analyze their velocity-time graphs.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, determined from the slope of the velocity-time graph.
Object A's graph shows a curve starting at \( v_0 \) and decreasing over time.
Object B's graph shows a straight line starting at \( v_0 \) and decreasing linearly over time.
The slope of the graph at any point represents the acceleration at that point.
For Object A, the slope at \( t_1 \) is the tangent to the curve at that point.
For Object B, the slope of the straight line is constant and calculated as the change in velocity divided by the change in time.
For Object A, the slope at \( t_1 \) is the tangent to the curve at \( t_1 \), which is not constant.
For Object B, the slope is constant and calculated as \( \frac{v_0}{t_4} \).
The slope of Object A at \( t_1 \) is not equal to the slope of Object B at \( t_1 \).
The two objects do not have the same acceleration at time \( t_1 \).
No, the two objects do not have the same acceleration at time \( t_1 \).
